title: Judges Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 20.

questions.question: Where did all the children of Israel gather together as one man in Judges 20?
questions.correctAnswer: Mizpeh
questions.explanation: All the children of Israel gathered together in Mizpeh as one man according to Judges 20:1.

questions.question: How many footmen that drew sword presented themselves in the assembly of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Four hundred thousand
questions.explanation: Judges 20:2 states that four hundred thousand footmen that drew sword presented themselves.

questions.question: Who was the husband of the woman that was slain in Gibeah?
questions.correctAnswer: The Levite
questions.explanation: The Levite was the husband of the woman that was slain, as mentioned in Judges 20:4.

questions.question: What did the Levite do with his concubine after the wickedness was committed?
options: Cut her in pieces and sent her throughout Israel
Took her back to his house
questions.correctAnswer: Cut her in pieces and sent her throughout Israel
questions.explanation: Judges 20:6 says the Levite cut his concubine in pieces and sent her throughout the inheritance of Israel.

questions.question: What was the response of all the people when they heard about the wickedness?
options: They arose as one man and refused to go to the tents of Benjamin
They decided to ignore the matter
questions.correctAnswer: They arose as one man and refused to go to the tents of Benjamin
questions.explanation: Judges 20:8 states that all the people arose as one man and said they would not go to Benjamin's tents.

questions.question: How many men of Benjamin were numbered that drew sword, excluding the inhabitants of Gibeah?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-six thousand
questions.explanation: Judges 20:15 records that twenty-six thousand Benjamites drew sword, besides the seven hundred chosen men of Gibeah.

questions.question: How many chosen men lefthanded were among the children of Benjamin?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven hundred
questions.explanation: Judges 20:16 mentions there were seven hundred chosen men lefthanded among Benjamin.

questions.question: Which tribe did the LORD say should go up first to battle against the children of Benjamin?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: In Judges 20:18, the LORD instructed that Judah should go up first to battle.

questions.question: How many men of Israel were destroyed by Benjamin on the first day of battle?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-two thousand
questions.explanation: Judges 20:21 states Benjamin destroyed twenty-two thousand men of Israel on the first day.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Israel fasted and offered burnt offerings before the LORD after the second day of battle.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 20:26 says Israel fasted and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.

questions.question: Who stood before the ark of the covenant when Israel inquired of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Phinehas, son of Eleazar
questions.explanation: Judges 20:28 identifies Phinehas, son of Eleazar, standing before the ark during the inquiry.

questions.question: How many men of Benjamin were destroyed by Israel on the third day of battle?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-five thousand and one hundred
questions.explanation: Judges 20:35 records that Israel destroyed twenty-five thousand and one hundred men of Benjamin on the third day.

questions.question: What was the appointed sign between the men of Israel and the liers in wait?
options: A great flame with smoke rising from the city
questions.correctAnswer: A great flame with smoke rising from the city
questions.explanation: Judges 20:38 describes the appointed sign as a great flame with smoke rising out of the city.

questions.question: True or False: The Benjamites were not amazed when they saw the flame of the city ascend to heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 20:41 states the Benjamites were amazed when they saw the flame of the city ascend.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After the battle, six hundred men of Benjamin fled to the wilderness unto the _____ Rimmon and abode there for four months.
questions.correctAnswer: rock
questions.explanation: Judges 20:47 says six hundred men fled to the wilderness unto the rock Rimmon for four months.

questions.question: True or False: The men of Israel set fire to all the cities of the children of Benjamin after the battle.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 20:48 confirms that Israel set fire to all the cities of Benjamin after smiting them.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is troubled by conflict in their church community and asks how to seek God's guidance before taking action. Based on Judges 20, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Pray and seek counsel from God before making decisions
Act immediately without waiting for God's direction
Ignore the conflict to keep peace
Rely only on human wisdom and advice
questions.correctAnswer: Pray and seek counsel from God before making decisions
questions.explanation: Judges 20:18 and Judges 20:23 show that the Israelites sought God's counsel before going to battle, demonstrating the importance of prayer and dependence on God for guidance.

questions.question: How does Judges 20 teach about the importance of unity among believers when facing challenges?
options: The congregation gathered as one man, showing unity is vital
Each tribe acted independently without consultation
Only the tribe of Judah acted while others stayed back
They ignored unity and fought separately
questions.correctAnswer: The congregation gathered as one man, showing unity is vital
questions.explanation: Judges 20:1 and Judges 20:11 describe the entire assembly of Israel coming together as one man, emphasizing unity in responding to a crisis.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness after a serious wrong. Based on Judges 20, what biblical principle about justice and reconciliation can you share?
options: Justice must be pursued before reconciliation can occur
Reconciliation should happen without addressing sin
Avoid confronting sin to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: Justice must be pursued before reconciliation can occur
questions.explanation: Judges 20:13 shows Israel demanding the wicked men be handed over for punishment, indicating that justice is necessary before restoration can be achieved.

questions.question: What does Judges 20 teach about the role of leadership and accountability within the community of faith?
options: Leaders must be accountable and present to guide the people
Leaders should remain silent during crises
Leadership is unnecessary in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must be accountable and present to guide the people
questions.explanation: Judges 20:2 describes the chiefs of all tribes presenting themselves to lead the assembly, illustrating the biblical role of accountable leadership.

questions.question: How does Judges 20 demonstrate the importance of integrity and honesty in confronting sin within the community?
options: The Levite openly reported the crime, showing honesty is essential
The crime was hidden to protect the city
People ignored the wrongdoing for convenience
questions.correctAnswer: The Levite openly reported the crime, showing honesty is essential
questions.explanation: In Judges 20:4-6, the Levite recounts the grievous sin openly, demonstrating the value of honesty in addressing evil.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to persevere through trials when initial efforts seem to fail. What does Judges 20 teach about persistence in seeking God's help?
options: They repeatedly sought God's counsel and continued the battle
They gave up after the first defeat
They blamed God for their failure
questions.correctAnswer: They repeatedly sought God's counsel and continued the battle
questions.explanation: Judges 20:23 and Judges 20:27-28 show Israel weeping, fasting, and repeatedly asking God for direction even after losses, teaching perseverance in spiritual dependence.

questions.question: How does Judges 20 instruct us about humility and reliance on God's power rather than human strength?
options: Israel sought God's guidance before battle, acknowledging their dependence
Israel relied only on their large army and weapons
They boasted of their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Israel sought God's guidance before battle, acknowledging their dependence
questions.explanation: Judges 20:18 and 20:28 emphasize Israel asking God who should lead the battle and trusting His deliverance, teaching reliance on God over human might.

questions.question: What practical lesson about church discipline and communal holiness can we learn from Judges 20?
options: The community confronted and acted against grievous sin to maintain holiness
Sin was tolerated to avoid conflict
Only private forgiveness mattered, not public action
They ignored sin for the sake of unity
questions.correctAnswer: The community confronted and acted against grievous sin to maintain holiness
questions.explanation: Judges 20:9-10 and 20:13 show Israel collectively addressing and punishing the wickedness in Benjamin to preserve holiness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 20, the Israelites were successful in battle solely because of their superior numbers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Despite having greater numbers (Judges 20:2, 20:17), Israel suffered heavy losses until they sought and obeyed God's guidance (Judges 20:23, 20:28), showing success depended on God's help.

questions.question: True or False: The Israelites' first response to the crime in Gibeah was to seek advice and counsel from each other.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 20:7-8 shows the Israelites asking for advice and all agreeing to act together, highlighting the importance of counsel and unity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Judges 20, the tribe of Benjamin had _____ men that could sling stones with great accuracy.
questions.correctAnswer: seven hundred chosen lefthanded
questions.explanation: Judges 20:16 specifies that among Benjamin were seven hundred chosen men who were lefthanded and skilled in slinging stones accurately.

questions.question: How does Judges 20 illustrate the importance of accountability within families and communities concerning moral failures?
options: The Levite held the community accountable by exposing the crime
Families ignored the wrongdoing to protect their members
Sin was kept secret within the tribe
Only individuals were held accountable, not the community
questions.correctAnswer: The Levite held the community accountable by exposing the crime
questions.explanation: Judges 20:4-6 shows the Levite making the grievous sin known to all Israel, demonstrating accountability beyond family to the whole community.

questions.question: What does Judges 20 teach about the importance of serving others and protecting the vulnerable within the community?
options: The assembly took collective action to punish those who harmed the vulnerable
They ignored the plight of the Levite's concubine
Each tribe protected only their own members
They avoided confronting evil to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: The assembly took collective action to punish those who harmed the vulnerable
questions.explanation: Judges 20:9-10 and 20:13 demonstrate Israel's joint response to evil done to a vulnerable woman, highlighting the call to protect the weak.

questions.question: How does Judges 20 show the role of worship and spiritual discipline in times of national crisis?
options: Israel fasted, wept, and offered sacrifices seeking God's favor
They neglected worship to focus on battle preparations
They relied solely on military strategy
They blamed God for their losses
questions.correctAnswer: Israel fasted, wept, and offered sacrifices seeking God's favor
questions.explanation: Judges 20:26 recounts the people fasting, weeping, and offering burnt and peace offerings, showing spiritual devotion during hardship.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and gratitude can be drawn from the Israelites' experience in Judges 20?
options: They humbled themselves before God, acknowledging His power and giving thanks
They boasted of their victories as their own achievement
They ignored God's role in their success
They blamed others for failures without self-examination
questions.correctAnswer: They humbled themselves before God, acknowledging His power and giving thanks
questions.explanation: Judges 20:26-28 shows Israel humbling themselves with fasting and seeking God's will, illustrating humility and gratitude.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 20.

questions.question: What was the initial gathering place of all the tribes of Israel before the battle against Benjamin?
questions.correctAnswer: Mizpeh
questions.explanation: All the children of Israel gathered together at Mizpeh before the battle, as stated in Judges 20:1.

questions.question: How many footmen did the tribes of Israel present themselves with for battle according to Judges 20?
questions.explanation: The chief men of all tribes presented themselves with 400,000 footmen who drew the sword, according to Judges 20:2.

questions.question: What action did the Levite take after the grievous sin committed in Gibeah?
options: Cut his concubine into pieces and sent her throughout Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Cut his concubine into pieces and sent her throughout Israel
questions.explanation: The Levite cut his concubine into pieces and sent her throughout all the inheritance of Israel as a call for justice, as seen in Judges 20:6.

questions.question: What was the response of the Israelites when the Levite asked for advice regarding the wickedness in Benjamin?
options: They rose as one man and refused to visit the tents of Benjamin
They sent a delegation to negotiate peace
questions.correctAnswer: They rose as one man and refused to visit the tents of Benjamin
questions.explanation: The Israelites responded by rising as one man, saying they would neither go to Benjamin's tents nor turn into their houses, as shown in Judges 20:8.

questions.question: How did the Israelites decide to execute their judgment on Gibeah?
options: By lot to select men from all tribes for battle
By sending a single representative to negotiate
By exiling the men of Gibeah
questions.correctAnswer: By lot to select men from all tribes for battle
questions.explanation: The Israelites planned to take men by lot from all tribes to bring provisions and to attack Gibeah, as per Judges 20:9-10.

questions.question: What unique skill did the seven hundred chosen men among Benjamin possess?
options: They were left-handed slingers who could hit a hair's breadth
They were renowned warriors with swords
questions.correctAnswer: They were left-handed slingers who could hit a hair's breadth
questions.explanation: Judges 20:16 details that seven hundred men were left-handed and could sling stones at a hair's breadth and not miss.

questions.question: Which tribe was instructed by the LORD to go first into battle against Benjamin?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: The LORD directed that Judah should go first into battle, as revealed in Judges 20:18.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the first day of battle between Israel and Benjamin?
questions.correctAnswer: Benjamin killed 22,000 Israelites
questions.explanation: On the first day, Benjamin destroyed 22,000 men of Israel, as stated in Judges 20:21.

questions.question: What did the Israelites do before the second day of battle when they sought the LORD's counsel?
options: They wept before the LORD until evening
questions.correctAnswer: They wept before the LORD until evening
questions.explanation: The people went up and wept before the LORD until evening and asked His counsel, as mentioned in Judges 20:23.

questions.question: How did the LORD respond to Israel's inquiry about going to battle again after the second day?
questions.correctAnswer: Go up against them
questions.explanation: The LORD instructed Israel to go up again against Benjamin after the second day, as given in Judges 20:23.

questions.question: What significant object was present at the house of God when Israel sought guidance?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ark of the Covenant
questions.explanation: The Ark of the Covenant was there in those days when Israel enquired of the LORD, as per Judges 20:27.

questions.question: Who stood before the Ark of the Covenant when Israel sought counsel in Judges 20?
questions.correctAnswer: Phinehas, son of Eleazar
questions.explanation: Phinehas, son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron, stood before the Ark in those days, as seen in Judges 20:28.

questions.question: What was the sign agreed upon between the Israelites and the liers in wait during the battle?
options: A great flame with smoke rising from the city
questions.correctAnswer: A great flame with smoke rising from the city
questions.explanation: The appointed sign was a great flame with smoke rising out of the city, as described in Judges 20:38.

questions.question: What was the fate of the city of Gibeah after the battle according to Judges 20?
options: It was destroyed by fire and the sword
It became the capital of Israel
It was abandoned but not destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: It was destroyed by fire and the sword
questions.explanation: Israel smote the cities with the sword and set them on fire, including Gibeah, as recorded in Judges 20:48.

questions.question: True or False: Benjamin had more men of war than all the other tribes of Israel combined.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Benjamin had 26,700 men, while the other tribes had 400,000 men of war, so they were outnumbered, as seen in Judges 20:15 and 20:17.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Judges 20 demonstrate about the communal responsibility of Israel in addressing sin within their midst?
options: They gather as one to seek God's counsel and act collectively against sin
Each tribe acts independently without consulting others
They ignore sin to maintain peace among tribes
Only the Levites have the authority to judge sin
questions.correctAnswer: They gather as one to seek God's counsel and act collectively against sin
questions.explanation: Judges 20:1-2 shows the entire congregation gathered from Dan to Beersheba to Mizpeh, acting as one man. They seek God's guidance before battle (verses 18, 23, 27-28). This reflects the biblical principle of corporate holiness and communal accountability (Leviticus 19:17-18; 1 Corinthians 5:1-5; Galatians 6:1).

questions.question: According to Judges 20, what was the immediate cause that led Israel to wage war against the tribe of Benjamin?
options: The grievous sin of the men of Gibeah involving the Levite’s concubine
A land dispute between Benjamin and Judah
A rebellion led by the tribe of Benjamin to overthrow Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The grievous sin of the men of Gibeah involving the Levite’s concubine
questions.explanation: Judges 20:4-6 reveals the Levite's testimony that the men of Gibeah of Benjamin committed a horrific act against his concubine, leading to her death. This sin caused Israel to seek justice (Romans 1:24-32; Psalm 106:35-39; 1 Corinthians 6:9-11).

questions.question: What does the response of the children of Israel in Judges 20:8-10 reveal about their attitude towards sin and justice?
options: They refuse to tolerate sin and plan a systematic response
They decide to ignore the sin to avoid conflict
They blame other tribes for the sin
They rely solely on prayer without action
questions.correctAnswer: They refuse to tolerate sin and plan a systematic response
questions.explanation: The people rise as one man and refuse to go to the offenders' tents (v8), instead planning to take ten men from each hundred, etc. (v9-10) to bring judgment on Gibeah. This shows their commitment to holiness and justice (Deuteronomy 17:7; Proverbs 28:5; Romans 13:3-4).

questions.question: How does Judges 20 illustrate the sovereign guidance of God in warfare?
options: Israel seeks God's direction before battle and follows His command for who leads
Israel fights without seeking God’s advice
God is silent during the conflict
The victory depends solely on Israel’s military strength
questions.correctAnswer: Israel seeks God's direction before battle and follows His command for who leads
questions.explanation: Verses 18 and 28 show Israel asking God who should go first in battle, and God commands Judah. God also promises victory on the third day (v28). This reveals God's providential control over national affairs (Exodus 14:14; 2 Chronicles 20:15; Psalm 20:7-8).

questions.question: What theological theme is revealed by Israel's repeated inquiries of the LORD before battle in Judges 20?
options: Dependence on divine guidance and acknowledgment of God’s sovereignty
Uncertainty and doubt about God's presence
Reliance on human wisdom over divine counsel
questions.correctAnswer: Dependence on divine guidance and acknowledgment of God’s sovereignty
questions.explanation: Israel repeatedly inquires of God (v18,23,27), demonstrating humility and dependence. This fits the biblical teaching of trusting God's wisdom over human strength (Psalm 37:5; Proverbs 3:5-6; James 1:5).

questions.question: What does the presence of seven hundred chosen left-handed slingers among Benjamin (Judges 20:16) signify about God's providence and human ability?
options: God equips His people with unique skills even in rebellion
Left-handedness is a sign of evil
Skill in battle guarantees divine approval
questions.correctAnswer: God equips His people with unique skills even in rebellion
questions.explanation: The left-handed slingers (v16) were highly effective, showing God’s providential gifting regardless of human sinfulness (Exodus 4:11; 1 Corinthians 12:4-11). However, skill does not imply righteousness (Ecclesiastes 9:11).

questions.question: How does Judges 20 depict the tragic consequences of unrepentant sin on a national level?
options: Massive loss of life and near destruction of the tribe of Benjamin
Immediate forgiveness and restoration without consequence
Blessing and prosperity following the sin
questions.correctAnswer: Massive loss of life and near destruction of the tribe of Benjamin
questions.explanation: The chapter shows thousands killed (v21,25,35,44,46) and Benjamin nearly wiped out (v47-48), demonstrating the devastating impact of sin unaddressed (Romans 1:18-32; Deuteronomy 28:15-68).

questions.question: What does the burning of the cities by the men of Israel (Judges 20:48) signify in the context of divine judgment and covenant holiness?
options: Complete purging of evil to maintain covenant purity
An act of mercy toward Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Complete purging of evil to maintain covenant purity
questions.explanation: Burning the cities (v48) represents thorough judgment against sin, consistent with Old Testament holiness laws requiring removal of evil (Deuteronomy 13:12-18; Leviticus 20:22-26; 2 Chronicles 29:5-11).

questions.question: What does the role of Phinehas in Judges 20:28 indicate about the priestly mediation and intercession in Israel’s warfare?
options: Priests intercede before God to seek His will for the nation
Priests are uninvolved in national decisions
Phinehas acts independently without God's direction
questions.correctAnswer: Priests intercede before God to seek His will for the nation
questions.explanation: Phinehas stands before the Ark to inquire God's will (v28), illustrating the priestly role of intercession and mediation (Exodus 28:1-3; Numbers 25:10-13; Hebrews 7:23-28).

questions.question: How does the unity of the tribes of Israel in Judges 20 reflect ecclesiological principles about the body of Christ?
options: Unity in doctrine and action is essential for God’s blessing
Each tribe or church should act independently
Unity is irrelevant to spiritual success
questions.correctAnswer: Unity in doctrine and action is essential for God’s blessing
questions.explanation: Israel gathers as one man (v1,11), demonstrating corporate unity vital for success and blessing (Psalm 133:1; John 17:21; Ephesians 4:3-6).

questions.question: What does the repeated defeat of Israel in the first two battles (Judges 20:21,25) teach about human effort and divine permission in discipline?
options: God may allow setbacks to humble His people and lead them to repentance
God always grants immediate victory to His people
Defeat means God has abandoned His people
Victory depends solely on numbers and weapons
questions.correctAnswer: God may allow setbacks to humble His people and lead them to repentance
questions.explanation: Israel suffers losses (v21,25) but responds with fasting and seeking God (v26-28), showing God’s discipline aims at repentance (2 Chronicles 7:14; Hebrews 12:5-11).

questions.question: What does the sign of the great flame with smoke (Judges 20:38-40) symbolize in God’s strategy and revelation?
options: God's sovereign control and the fulfillment of the appointed plan
A random military tactic without spiritual meaning
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign control and the fulfillment of the appointed plan
questions.explanation: The flame was a prearranged signal (v38-40) indicating God's orchestration of battle events, consistent with His providential guidance (Genesis 15:17; Exodus 13:21-22; Isaiah 55:8-11).

questions.question: In Judges 20, how does the near annihilation of Benjamin contribute to the biblical theme of judgment and mercy in the covenant community?
options: It shows serious consequences for covenant unfaithfulness but also the preservation of some for restoration
It means God rejects the entire tribe without hope
It indicates God punishes only individuals, not groups
It shows God’s indifference to covenant violations
questions.correctAnswer: It shows serious consequences for covenant unfaithfulness but also the preservation of some for restoration
questions.explanation: Though 25,100 men fall (v46), 600 survive (v47), reflecting judgment balanced with mercy and hope for restoration (Jeremiah 30:11; Hosea 6:1-3; Romans 11:1-5).

questions.question: What Christological connection can be drawn from Israel's reliance on God's word and presence in battle in Judges 20?
options: Christ as the true King and mediator who leads His people to victory over sin and death
Christ is absent from Old Testament battles
Victory depends on human strength alone
God’s presence is conditional on sacrifices only
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the true King and mediator who leads His people to victory over sin and death
questions.explanation: Israel’s reliance on God’s direction (v18,23,27-28) foreshadows Christ’s role as King and High Priest (Hebrews 4:14-16; Revelation 19:11-16; John 15:5).

questions.question: What does the repeated seeking of God’s counsel in Judges 20 teach about the role of the Holy Spirit in guiding God's people?
options: The Spirit guides believers into God’s will and empowers obedience
The Spirit is irrelevant to decision making
Believers rely solely on human wisdom
God’s guidance is unpredictable and random
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit guides believers into God’s will and empowers obedience
questions.explanation: Israel’s inquiries (v18,23,27) illustrate dependence on God’s Spirit for direction, consistent with New Testament teaching about the Spirit (John 16:13; Romans 8:14; Galatians 5:16-25).

questions.question: How does Judges 20 fit into the grand biblical narrative concerning sin, judgment, and redemption?
options: It shows the destructive consequences of sin and the need for God's deliverance
It teaches that sin has no consequences
It portrays a perfect human society without sin
It denies God’s involvement in human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the destructive consequences of sin and the need for God's deliverance
questions.explanation: The chapter highlights sin’s devastation (v21,46), judgment (v48), and dependence on God’s guidance (v18,28), aligning with biblical themes of fall and redemption (Genesis 3; Romans 3:23-26; Revelation 21:1-5).
